definitions.definition: to tell somebody that you will definitely do or not do something, or that something will definitely happen
definitions.sensetop: promise to do somethingpromise somethingpromise (that)…promise somebody (that)…promise something to somebodypromise somebody somethingpromise yourself somethingpromise (somebody) + speech

examples.text: ‘We haven't got time to go to the park.’ ‘But you promised!’
The college principal promised to look into the matter.
‘Promise not to tell anyone!’ ‘I promise.’
They arrived at 7.30 as they had promised.
The government has promised a full investigation into the disaster.
I'll see what I can do but **I can't promise anything**.
The brochure promised (that) the local food would be superb.
You promised me (that) you’d be home early tonight.
He promised the money to his grandchildren.
He promised his grandchildren the money.
I've promised myself some fun when the exams are over.
‘I'll be back soon,’ she promised.
He repeatedly promised to cut taxes in his campaign.
I am sending you information on holidays as promised.
I can definitely promise you that I'll do all I can to help.
I can't promise I'll be there.
She promised faithfully that she would come.
I've promised my old computer to Jane.

definitions.definition: to make something seem likely to happen; to show signs of something
definitions.sensetop: it promises to be somethingpromise something

examples.text: It promises to be an exciting few days.
There were dark clouds overhead promising rain.
The plan seemed to promise a new beginning.
It was a disappointing end to a season which had promised so much for the team.
The new drug promises to bring relief to thousands of asthma sufferers.

definitions.definition: used as a way of encouraging or warning somebody about something

examples.text: I can promise you, you'll have a wonderful time.
If you don't take my advice, you'll regret it, I promise you.

definitions.definition: to make promises that will be impossible to keep

examples.text: Politicians promise the earth before an election, but things are different afterwards.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin promissum ‘something promised’, neuter past participle of promittere ‘put forth, promise’, from pro- ‘forward’ + mittere ‘send’.
